div.ab:
ἔδωκεν ὁ θεοφιλέστατος Θεόδωρος Ὀβοδιανοῦ λόγῳ συντελειῶν
αὐτοῦ ἀπὸ τῆς νυνὶ διελθούσης πρώτης ἰνδικτίωνος μέχρι τῆς
παρούσης ἕκτης καὶ αὐτῆς ἐτῶν ἓξ, ὑπὲρ τῶν
χωρίων περιελθόντων εἰς αὐτὸν
είας τόπου Χαφα
τόπου Μαλ
εἰκοστὸν
λεγομένου τόπου Μαλ Σαρ αδ
τριακοστὸν ἑβδομηκοστὸν
ἐνενηκοστὸν πάντα τὰ ἀπαιτηθέντα καὶ ἐπικλασθέντα
ἔν τε γενήμασιν καὶ οἰνοκρέοις καὶ πλ εἴδεσιν ἀκολούθως
τῇ θείᾳ δηληγατίονιδηληγατίωνι. ἐγράφη μηνὶ ἔτους ἰνδικτίωνος ἕκτης.
Φλάουιος Πατρίκιος Αἰλιανοῦ συναπέσχον τὸ μέρος
ἥμισυ τῶν προγεγραμμένων συντελειῶν
ἐνενηκοστοῦἐνεκοστοῦ ἀπὸ πρότηςπρώτης μέχρι τῆς παρούσης
ἕκτης ἐπινεμήσεωςἐπινεμέσεος καὶ αὐτῆς ἐτῶν ἓξ
ἀκολούθως ὑπογράψας χειρὶ ἐμῇ.
Φλάουιος Αἰλιανὸς Μοναξίου συναπέσχον τὸ
μέρος ἥμισυ τῶν προγεγραμμένων συντελειῶν ἀπὸ πρώτης μέχρι
ἕκτης ἰνδικτίωνος καὶ αὐτῆς ἐτῶν ἓξ ἀκολούθως ὑπογράψας
χειρὶ ἐμῇ.

div.p: Translation (1. H.) [†] The most God-pleasing [Theodoros, son of Obodianos,] has given [on account of his taxes, from the] now passed [first indiction until the] present sixth [and including it, for six years,] for . . . landed property that devolved [on him . . .] the place Khafa . . . the place Mal . . . . . one twentieth . . . for the place called Mal Sar . . . one thirtieth, one seventieth, [making together?. . . ] one ninetieth, all the [exacted and extra (taxes) in] farm products and in oinokreon [and in ? products according to] the imperial delegatio. Written in the month . . . of the year . . . in the sixth indiction]. (2. H.) [†] I, Flavius Patrikios, son of Ailianos, [ . . . have received (jointly?)] one half [part] of the above-written [taxes . . . ] one ninetieth, from the first [ . . . to the present] sixth indiction and [including it, six years, . . . ] having signed accordingly [with my own hand. †] (3. H.) [†] I Flavius Ailianos, son of Monaxios, [ . . . have received jointly] one half part of the above-written [taxes, from the first to the] sixth indiction and including it, [six] years, [having signed accordingly] with my own hand. †

Commentary 1 [ἔδω]κεν ὁ θεοφιλέϲτ(ατοϲ) Θ[εόδωροϲ Ὀβοδιανοῦ: the latest document where Theodoros is still a layman, εὐδοκιμώτατοϲ, is 23 (544), while the earliest to record him as a cleric, θεοφιλέϲτατοϲ, is 25 (559). This receipt may date from the sixth indiction that had just preceded it (557/58), or the next one (572/73). The initial theta of Theodoros’ name is very large and part of it was written over twice.
3–4 The text might have run, e.g., ὑπὲρ τῶν χ]ωρίων περιελθόντω[ν εἰϲ αὐτὸν ἀπὸ πατρῴαϲ αὐτοῦ κληρονομίαϲ. However, there would still have been space at the end of l. 3.
5–10 Several different plots of land are recorded together with fractions which must have referred to their taxation value. The last string of fractions around the gap in ll. 9–10 would be exceptionally long, unless there were in fact two series, the last summing up all the preceding ones. Note, however, that the reading [ἐνεν]η̣κ̣[οϲτὸ]ν̣ in l. 10 is all but certain, based on the same fraction (misspelled) in Patrikios’ signature in l. 15. For the fractions in general, cf. Introduction to 7–10 and Introduction to 19.
5 τό(που) Χαφα̣[: several toponyms in 17 start with χαφ-, but they always have a double phi, e.g., Χαφφι Φοϲεα (l. 62), αλ-Βερ Αμ αλ-Χαφφα (l. 69), Χαφφαθ Μαθ Λελα (l. 118). The letter before the gap looks like an alpha, so it is possible that the name here derives from the masculine kaf (“palm of the hand”); see al-Ghul, Preliminary Notes, 160.
6–8 For Arabic Mal (“property”), see 45 6 comm. The stroke after the rho of Ϲαρ should be read as punctuation rather than as an abbreviation mark, suggesting how the letters should be read in connection with what follows.
10–11 For the expression and the nature of these taxes (connected with the annona militaris), see 45 9–10 with comm. With these restorations, line 11 is somewhat too short and may have contained an extra word, unless the enigmatic abbreviation πλ( ) was written in full.
11–12 ἀκολούθωϲ τῇ̣] θείᾳ δηληγατίονι: see 20 6–7 comm. and 32 2–4 comm.
13 ϲυναπέϲχον: cf. 45 17, 20; the verb might here have been simply ἀπέϲχον (“received”), with the compound ϲυναπέϲχον (“received jointly”) appearing only in the second signature. Both here and in l. 18, a title, like κόμεϲ, πολιτ(ευόμενοϲ), or πρωτεύων, probably followed after the name, see 45 13, 17, and 20 comm.
15–16 ἀπ(ὸ) πρότη[ϲ c. 8? μέχρι τῆϲ παρούϲηϲ] [ἕκ]τ̣ηϲ ἐπινεμέϲεοϲ καὶ̣ [αὐτῆϲ ἐτῶν ἓξ: another way to fill the gap would be to list all the relevant indictions: ἀπ(ὸ) πρότη[ϲ, δευτέραϲ, τρίτηϲ, τετάρτηϲ, πέμπτηϲ, ἕκτ]ηϲ; this would fit the line exactly but would not be quite natural after the preposition ἀπό.
18 Αἰλιανὸϲ: a short oblique stroke through the first iota makes it look like a cross.
19 μ̣έ̣ρ̣(οϲ) (ἥμισυ) τ̣[ῶ]ν: only the lower parts of the letters survive, and an oblique stroke through the rho probably marks the abbreviation. The lower traces of a character before the tau do not look like any of the surviving letters. It may be a symbol for ἥμιϲυ (“half”).
